text: inch by nerve-racking inch for more than
two weeks Tommy Caldwell in Kevin
jorgeson have been scaling this massive
slab of granite hoping to become the
first to free climb El Capitan said to
be the hardest climb in the world as it
goes on you feel a little bit more hope
and now we're at a point where you know
it's this is this is really gonna happen
but it won't all we won't feel the whole
immensity of it until they're standing
on top they've been using only their
fingertips and feet to grasp hoist and
pull their way across 32 sections of
this treacherous terrain ropes only used
as protection from plunging below as
well as that drop they've had to contend
with razor-sharp edges and frigid winds
their only shelter these tents suspended
from a single point the two climbers are
almost at the top of El Capitan which is
about 900 meters tall and as steep as
the side of a skyscraper so how does
this slab of granite compare to man-made
structures the climbers have already
climbed the length of London shard at
308 metres El Capitan even Dwarfs the
world's tallest building
Dubai's Burj Khalifa at 828 meters the
climbers have been taken to social media
to post updates and document their
progress a recent tweet by Kevin
jorgeson nothing like clouds in a cold
breeze to boost motivation for the hard
day ahead you can see they're climbing
at night quite a lot which is because
friction is better when it's cooler so
even in December or January in
California it's still quite warm so
they're actually climbing by night to
try and find that a little bit more
friction you know these guys are on the
edge of impossible what they're trying
to do right now and now and they're
getting very close just meters away from
realizing their dream and making history
Laura Westbrook BBC News
